metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

abstract.gco:CharacterString: Statewide coverage of 1940 Places based on population data available from the U.S. Bureau of the Census. Population data is from the Sixteenth Census of the United States (1940 Census of Population)

purpose.gco:CharacterString: To use in GIS systems for historical study and analysis This datasets is made available to interested persons through the University of Arizona's instance of Open Geoportal. It has been provided to assist educators, students, researchers, and policy makers in mapping and/or analysis applications.

credit.gco:CharacterString: Chris Kollen, University of Arizona Library

title.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: Reference to a formally registered thesaurus or a similar authoritative source of theme keywords.

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.2.1350

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Digitized city boundaries from the following maps: Buckeye, Chandler, Gilbert, Glendale, Mesa, Phoenix, Tempe, Tolleson, and Wickenburg used Maricopa County Annexation File; Casa Grande used Casa Grande, 1940 (Sanborn); Clifton used Map of Greenlee County, 1916 (no changes until 1970); Douglas used Atlas of Cochise County, 1937; Duncan used Duncan, 1950; Flagstaff used City of Flagstaff, a planning and zoning map for annexation; Globe used Map of Gila County, 1941; Holbrook used Holbrook, 1943 (Sanborn); Jerome used Map of the town of Jerome, Yavapai County, Arizona, 1938; Miami used Miami 1948 (Sanborn); Nogales used Map of Nogales, 1940; Pima used Map of Pima, Territory of Arizona, County of Graham, 1887 (no changes until 1960); Prescott used City of Prescott Annexation History, 2007; Safford used Official Map of the Town of Safford and Additions, April-May 1916 (no changes until 1960); Somerton used City of Somerton Annexation map; South Tucson used Tucson Annexation Boundary File; Thatcher used Official Map of Thatcher, 1902 (no changes until 1970); Tombstone used Tombstone, Arizona, 1882 (Sanborn; no changes until 1960); Tucson used Tucson Annexation Boundary File; Winslow used General Highway and Transportation Map, Navajo County. 1937, and Yuma used City of Yuma Annexation map. For remaining places, used Geographic Names Information System database for point data. Created a 200 meter buffer around all point data in order to convert into polygons.

value.gco:Record: Accuracy ranges from ~10 meters (Scale 1:600) to ~50 meters (Scale 1:63,360).

description.gco:CharacterString: Dataset renamed from 1940_Cities.shp to Arizona_CensusPlaces_1940.shp by Ben Hickson with the University of Arizona Library. Metadata fields corresponding the Open Geoportal Working Group Best Practices Guide (http://opengeoportal.org/working-groups/metadata/) were also updated.

title.gco:CharacterString: Official Map of the Town of Safford and Additions, April-May 1916.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Compiled from surveys by R.J. Young, City Engineer

title.gco:CharacterString: Map of Pima, Territory of Arizona, County of Graham.
General Highway and Transportation Map, Navajo County.
Map of the town of Jerome, Yavapai County, Arizona.
City of Flagstaff, a planning and zoning map for annexation

description.gco:CharacterString: Arizona Highway Dept. Photogrammetry and Mapping Division

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Arizona Highway Dept. Photogrammetry and Mapping Division

description.gco:CharacterString: Dept. of Community Development, GIS Work Group
